title: INFLUENCE OF DRUG-POLYMER INTERACTIONS ON RELEASE KINETICS OF PLGA AND PLA/PEG NPS

authors.name: Carlos Aleman
affiliations: Barcelona Research Center for Multiscale Science and Engineering, EEBE, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya

authors.name: Enrica Chiesa
affiliations: 1Department of Drug Sciences, University of Pavia

summary: Research investigates antimicrobial drug delivery systems using microfluidic-synthesized nano-carriers, focusing on PLGA and PLA/PEG. Results show improved encapsulation efficiency and controlled release rates for curcumin-loaded PLGA NPs due to hydrophobic interactions.
methods: Custom-built microfluidic device with a Passive Herringbone Mixer (PHBM) chip was used for synthesizing PLGA and PLA/PEG nanoparticles (NPs) via microfluidics. The encapsulation efficiency, physical properties, and release kinetics of curcumin-loaded NPs were analyzed.
results: NPs had uniform size distribution with PDI <=0.2. Higher encapsulation efficiency (EE%) was observed for curcumin-loaded PLGA NPs compared to PLA/PEG micelles. Curcumin-loaded PLGA NPs showed slower release rates and no or slight cytotoxic effects on NHDFs. The choice of polymer composition played a crucial role in drug-polymer interactions and release kinetics.
